fields.summary: Improve documentation for the /share Rest API function

fields.description:
The feature to add group of users as reviewers to CRUC-474 seems to be conflicting when the project has allowed users/groups restriction.

Basically with no users/groups restriction user can filter users/groups by its name prefix in the Edit Review dialog and pick up individual users or groups to be added to the review.  This works as expected.

But if the project has restriction of users/groups allowed, it behaves wrongly.
 1. if users with given prefix are found as allowed reviewers (either allowed users or members of allowed groups), only those users are listed in the Reviewers input.  This seems fine
 2. but if such users are found, the Reviewers input shows all group and users with the given prefix, regardless whether they are allowed as reviewers or not on this project.  It is most likely possible to add those users as reviewers to review, regardless of the allowed reviewers restrictions.
fields.summary: adding reviewers group conflicts with allowed groups

fields.description:

Screenshot: http://dl.dpeck.net/15j13

"You are running release CR3.6.4 FE3.6.4 (20150123083607 2015-01-23), please report your release number when reporting bugs. "
fields.summary: Firefox OS X (v37) often fails to receive a successful AJAX response

fields.description:
When a user that has reviews associated to them is renamed the user can no longer see the associated reviews on their personal activity stream. 

A Crucible Reindex fixes this but this should update itself automatically.

Steps to reproduce;

# Rename a User that has reviews associated to them
# Navigate to user's home dashboard (Select the user's Avatar in the top right and then select Activity)
# No reviews are displayed
fields.summary: Renamed user no longer sees reviews in Personal Activity Stream

fields.description:
When doing a review in crucible, it seems that the scroll position is kept in memory and applied to the next selected file.

So if I execute a review of the file A and scroll all the way to the bottom, and then select the file B to do the review of the next file, the scollbar will already be scroll to the bottom or halfway depending of the review size.

It's very annoying since when I start a new file review, I want to start from the beginning, not the end.

I've reproduced the problem on Chrome and Firefox.

I've checked the most recent release notes and did not see any fix about that issue.

We're synced with a perforce repository if this is usefull!
fields.summary: Scroll position
Branch review auto update

It is not possible to click through to a user by clicking the name in the Review page "more reviewers" popup. Avatars are proper links and work fine, but not the names.
fields.summary: User links broken on review page "more reviewers" popup

fields.description:
When a file is added on a branch, it should be added as an added revision to the branch review.
If updated later on, it should have two revisions, but only the last one should be visible in full (currently the diff is shown, which is wrong: https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/cru/CR-FE-8911#CFR-140493)
fields.summary: Files added in a branch should be shown as added in the branch review

fields.description:
Plugins distributed via Marketplace and marked compatible with Crucible product only(not Fisheye) are marked as incompatible with both applications (also with Fisheye + Crucible).

This results with INCOMPATIBLE mark on all installed plugins compatible only with Crucible. Any of these plugins can be installed via "Find New Add-ons" functionality.
fields.summary: Plugins compatible with Crucible only are shown as incompatible.

fields.description:
Right now when user not mapped correctly to committers NPE is throw. Plugin checks all users mappings so this can result with NPEs when i.e. some dummy user is created.

Expected behaviour. Log proper error/warning message or throw some more meaningful exception. Plugin could verify only necessary user-commiter mappings.
fields.summary: Reviewcreator plugin should show proper error when user is not correctly mapped to commiter
JIRA issues auto-link incorrectly when surrounded with quotes

fields.description:
h3. Summary

New files that have been added in a patch file in a pre-commit review do not contain a {{View}} button when viewing a diff or a file for iterations added afterward in order to view more context. 

h3. Expected Behaviour

The {{View}} button should be available in order to view more context, as is present for files that have previously been added.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a new file to a repository. For example {{echo a > text.txt; svn add test.txt}}.
# Make a change to an existing file so that the patch is correctly anchored to the repository.
# Create a diff. {{svn diff > patch.txt}}.
# Upload the patch as a pre-commit review. Note that it is correctly anchored, and Crucible notices {{test.txt}} as a new file.
# Make another change to {{text.txt}}. For example {{echo a >> test.txt}}.
# Create a new patch file. {{svn diff > patch2.txt}}.
# Upload this new patch to the review, making sure to anchor to the first patch.
# Note that the {{View}} button is not present.
fields.summary: "View" Button Missing For Newly Added Files in Pre-Commit Reviews

fields.description:
This was done in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-1014. The problem is that I may scroll past comments without actually reading them. Then, when I scroll back, I no longer have any way to know which comments I haven't read yet. 

This can be very frustrating when there are a large number of comment, some read, some new. 

This is especially a problem with comments on attached files (like Word docs), because in order to download the file, I need to scroll past all comments to the bottom of the page.

I would really like a way to disable this behavior.
fields.summary: Disable "Mark comments as read by scrolling past them"

Workaround is to perform a manual Crucible reindex.
fields.summary: Changing a project key doesn't update the review index

fields.description:
If only Crucible is in use (no FishEye license) and the Crucible license is changed (i.e. for a new Evaluation license), the repository stops due to incompatibility with the license:
!license1.png|thumbnail!

I observed that, when installing only Crucible, at the first time the FishEye license is shown as *Evaluation*, and Crucible shows a FishEye SEN as being the same of Crucible SEN:
!license2.png|thumbnail!

By the moment the license is edited and the Crucible license is replaced (by a new one, for example), the FishEye license goes from *Evaluation* to *Disabled*, causing the issue, even if the repository was never indexed with a FishEye license in place.
* Before editing:
!license3.png|thumbnail!
* After editing:
!license4.png|thumbnail!

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Download and install [Crucible|https://www.atlassian.com/software/crucible/download].
# During initial setup, insert the Crucible license.
# After completing the install, add a repository and let it complete the indexing.
# Generate a new Crucible license.
# Go to {{Administration > System Info}}, click in *Edit License*, replace the current Crucible license by the new one and save it. At this point you will notice the FishEye is Disabled (there will be no FishEye SEN anymore).
!license5.png|thumbnail!
# Restart Crucible. After the restart the repository will be stopped, and it will not be possible to start it unless a FishEye license is obtained or the repository is re-indexed.
fields.summary: Repository stops after changing Crucible license

fields.description:
Our company uses multiple Atlassian products, like Jira, Confluence, Bamboo and Crucible. For source code control we are using PlasticSCM since it's the best state of the art tool for that. We have experiences with git, subversion, cvs and mercuical but all of them are not a patch on PlasticSCM. Unfortunately non of the Atlassian products supports PlasticSCM directly.

Currently we are using the PlasticSCM plugins provides by Codice. But most of the time there are not as nice integrated as the repositories which are directly supported by Atlassian. 

We think it is necessary for Atlassian to support PlasticSCM natively, since it's the best SCM system on the market, at least in our opinion. The native support would add value to all Atlassian products.

Especially Fisheye would benefit of a PlasticSCM support, since there isn't a plugin available yet. If you would integrate PlasticSCM support to Fisheye, we would immediatly buy a License for our Company. And I am sure others will do the same!
fields.summary: Adding Plastic SCM repository support

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When setting up an Application Link between JIRA and Crucible, then try to reopen an already closed issue from Crucible if there is the Assignee field in a screen, the field drop-down won't be render when transitioning the issue from Crucible.

h3. Steps to reproduce

# Create an Application Link between JIRA and Crucible.
# In JIRA create a test Project.
# Use the workflow "classic default workflow" in this project, which has the assignee field in the screens of the transitions.
# Create a test issue, and close the issue.
# In Crucible, create a new review linking to this test issue.
# Open the closed issue in Crucible, and try to transition the issue clicking in "Reopen"
# It will bring the screen with the assignee field, however, there is a drop-down that doesn't render properly.

It appears that any transition containing the Assignee field in a screen will not render that field.

h3. Expected behaviour

Render the Assignee field with the possible options to reassign the issue.

h3. Actual Results
The assignee field drop down does not render properly

h3. Workaround

Remove the field from the screens in the transitions, or simply press enter when performing the transition, the issue will be transitioned without changing the Assignee field.


h3. Note
*Reporter* field is also affected
fields.summary: Crucible does not render Assignee field properly.

fields.description:
*Advanced Search* is a feature of FishEye and so can't be utilised if only Crucible is licensed. 

However the *Advanced Search* link is still present on the search page in Crucible and when selected a _Page not found_ is displayed.

It would be more informal to the customer if either this *Advanced Search* link was removed or some information was given to the customer after following the link regarding the need for the presence of FishEye.

Please see below provided screenshots

!1.JPG|thumbnail! 

!2.JPG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: When trying to perform an Advanced Search in Crucible the user is greeted with "Page Cannot Be Found"

fields.description:
Currently, the {{crucible.py}} command line script does not support [Git SVN|http://git-scm.com/book/en/v1/Git-and-Other-Systems-Git-and-Subversion] repositories, an error is encountered when attempting to anchor the patch to the repository. I believe this is caused by the difference between a Git patch and a SVN patch and FishEye not being able to anchor the different patch files.

*Steps to Reproduce*

# Clone a SVN repository using Git
{code}git svn clone file:///path/to/svn -s{code}
# Make changes to the repository
# Run the {{crucible.py}} utility to create a review:
{code}master(+2/-0) ±‡ ~/crucible.py -r svn-test
Crucible server: http://fisheye.company.com:8060
Crucible username: jeff
No staged changes were found in the repository, creating a review for all unstaged changes.
Please specify a project to create the review in or an existing review id to add to [CR]: 
Please specify the review title: Test
Please specify a reviewer to be added to the review, or press Enter to continue: 
Error: Failed to anchor the patch to repository svn-test, please check that the repository is the correct one{code}

fields.description:
Observed on Yosemite, osx.

This happens when LC_ALL and LANG is not set:

{code}
Python 2.7.9 (default, Dec 15 2014, 10:01:34) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 6.0 (clang-600.0.56)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import locale
>>> locale.getdefaultlocale
<function getdefaultlocale at 0x100e846e0>
>>> locale.getdefaultlocale()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/locale.py", line 543, in getdefaultlocale
    return _parse_localename(localename)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/locale.py", line 475, in _parse_localename
    raise ValueError, 'unknown locale: %s' % localename
ValueError: unknown locale: UTF-8

{code}

export LANG=en_US.UTF-8
{code}

fields.description:
Crucible could have a "concurrent review" feature similar to Confluence's concurrent editing to allow users working on the same review at the same time to see the lines of code in which each user is working on.

The idea is to avoid people to work in the same part at the same time, and also not having to refresh the page to see changes made by other users.
fields.summary: Concurrent review

When a perforce commit has the following message:

The commit is not displayed in the "Development" section of the issue in JIRA.

"Some pre-message: IMS-6950 Added a dummy file."

JIRA version=v6.3.11#6341-sha1:83c4d29

I have read the [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Viewing+an+Issue%27s+FishEye+Changesets] and there are no mentions of the handling of colons.
fields.summary: Commit not recognized in JIRA when issue key is followed by colon

fields.description:
For queries with an IN clause we use HqlBatchedInClauseHelper that splits the query into a number of queries, where each subquery's in clause is limited to a number of items (100 by default), to better support certain DBMSes which have trouble with large IN clauses.

The subqueries generated by HqlBatchedInClauseHelper are then iterated, which can be problematic if the base query is expected to be cached. The iterated queries don't go through Hibernate's query cache, potentially causing them to be executed a bunch of times.

This affects a few areas of the application, notably checking project permissions.
fields.summary: Queries with IN clauses not cached properly

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In FishEye/Crucible, if a user is managed externally (i.e. JIRA/Crowd/LDAP), and local editing of email address and display name is disabled, it is not possible to enable or disable Crucible access for that user.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Integrate Crucible with JIRA for user management.
#* For *When synchronisation happens* set *Copy new users and changes to existing users (local editing of email address and display name is disabled).*
# Synchronize the users.
# Within Crucible edit a user, uncheck the box *Crucible user* and click in *Apply*. It will fail because the user is managed externally so no changes can be applied. See screenshot below
!crucible_user_error.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results
Crucible access for the user should be editable, as this is not managed externally.

h3. Actual Results
Crucible access cannot be edited if the user is managed externally, and local editing of email address and display name is disabled.

h3. Workaround 1 - Bulk Edit
# Under {{Administration >> User Settings >> Users}} select the checkbox for the users that you would like to enable/disable Crucible for
# At the bottom of the page, select "Enable Crucible" or "Disable Crucible" in the Bulk actions dropdown menu and select "GO"

h3. Workaround 2
# Go to {{Crucible Administration > Authentication > JIRA/Crowd Authentication}}, edit its setting and set *When synchronisation happens* to *Copy only new users (local editing of email address and display name is enabled)* temporarily. Proceed with the groups configuration and Save.
# Within Crucible edit the user, checking/unchecking the *Crucible user* box. It will work now as for now it is possible to edit users locally.
# Go back to {{Crucible Administration > Authentication > JIRA/Crowd Authentication}} and edit the settings to set *When synchronisation happens* back to the previous setting.

h3. Workaround 3 - REST API
An example of how you could enable a user for Crucible access is as follows:
{noformat}
curl -u <ADMIN USER> -v -X PUT -d "{\"crucible\":true}" -H "Content-Type: application/json" <URL>:<PORT>/rest-service-fecru/admin/users/<USERNAME>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Unable to edit "Crucible user" setting for externally managed users

fields.description:
The current project list UI does not support filtering, so for installations with many projects I have to paginate through to find a particular project or search for it.  Would like to have a filter field (similar to the filters used on the Users admin screen).

The project admin screen is better since it is not paginated (and I can use the browser's text search), but it could also benefit from a filter field.
fields.summary: Add filters to project list

fields.description:
I tried crucible with two different setups:
linux with mysql 5.5
windows with mssql 2012
Mercurial repository

With both setups it is nearly impossible create reviews if the review contains a file with many changes (1,4mb, 40.000 lines and 10.000 changes). 
Browser will freeze (tried with opera, chrome, firefoxe, ie).
Crucible will allocate more than 3gigabyte memory on the host machine.
(server is a dell server with 6 cores and 50gig ram).
fields.summary: Crucible extremly slow if file contains many changes.

fields.description:
The [reviewcreator plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.plugins.reviewcreator] is marked as *Incompatible* specifically in Crucible 3.6.2, though in the plugin page it is said it is compatible with this version.

It is installed without issues in version 3.6.1.

fields.description:
h4. Symptons

When trying to view a review as an *anonymous user* the below error is shown;

!Screen Shot 2014-12-16 at 17.21.26.png|thumbnail!

h4. Cause

A group is used to restrict access to the Crucible project via _Allowed Review Participants_. It does not matter if the group is populated with users or not. 

h4. Steps to reproduce
1. create a review with login user
2. set a group to allow reviewer participant
3. access the review without login

h4. Workaround 

Add the users individually to _Allowed Review Participants_
fields.summary: Error 'Problems calling function 'crev:showJoinReview' is displayed when attempting to view a review as an anonymous user when a group is used in 'Allowed Review Participants'

fields.description:
If you create two projects in Crucible, one which contains the whole contents of a repository, and one that contains only a path, if you create a review from a smart commit in a path not contained in that second project, it will still create the review in that second project.

Steps to reproduce:
# Create a project called {{A}} that contains a path of a repository. (i.e. {{/foo}}).
# Create a project called {{B}} that contains that entire repository.
# Perform a smart commit with {{+review}} (without specifying the project) to a path not contained in project {{A}}.  (i.e. {{bar/test.txt}}).
# The review will be created in {{A}}, even though {{A}} does not contain that path.

I also noticed that if you rename {{A}} to {{C}}, this does not occur. I am not sure if it picks the first relevant repository.
fields.summary: Smart Commits Creates Review In Project Not Containing That FishEye Content

fields.description:
We have discovered and fixed a vulnerability in our fork of WebWork. Attackers can use this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that use this framework. The attacker needs to be able to access the Crucible web interface.

All versions of Crucible up to and including 3.6.1 are affected by this vulnerability.The vulnerability has been fixed in recent releases 3.5.5 and 3.6.2.

For additional details see the full advisory.
fields.summary: OGNL Double Evaluation Vulnerability

fields.description:
It is not possible to add two new files with the same name coming from different repositories to the same review. When the first file is already added, Crucible shows the other, coming from the different repository, as already added. If the file from the second repository is then selected and added, Crucible replaces the existing one.

*Scenario*
* *git* repository, containing file named *file*, just created.
* *svn* repository, containing file named *file*, just created.

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Create a review and add content selecting option *Explore repositories*.
# Browse the *git* repository, select *file* and click in *Done*.
# Click to add more content, selecting *Explore repositories*.
# Change repository to *svn*, then check on *file*. In the REV column it will be showing the version of the file previously added, coming from the other repository:
!review1.png|thumbnail!
# Changing the version in the dropdown list and clicking in Done will replace the file in the review by the version select.

*Workaround*
# Create separate reviews for these files.

*Additional Note*
It was observed, however, that files with the same name under the status "Changed" (not new in the repository) can be added to the same review. The same behavior is observed (when browsing the other repo, the file is marked as already added), but selecting the version from the other repository in the dropdown list and clicking in *Done* will add it to the review, separately from the existing one. See screenshot below:
!review2.png|thumnail!
* The file named *file* colored in blue is changed, so it is possible to have it from both repositories in the same review as a separate file.
* The files *readme* and *metadata.rb* are new, so they are replaced if selecting them from the other repository.
fields.summary: Can't review new files with the same name from different repositories

fields.description: A URL with both a # and a ? in it still does not link properly in Crucible.
fields.summary: CRUC-5238 fix does not cover all cases - urls with both hash (#) and ? in Crucible do not link properly

fields.summary: Attempting to obtain a connection from a pool that has already been shutdown

fields.description:
The feature to re-anchor a patch has been removed in Crucible 3.0, but documentation still contains screenshot displaying "edit" link.
See https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Creating+patch+files+for+pre-commit+reviews
fields.summary: Patch documentation out of date

fields.summary: Slow loadFrxAjax caused by blame (getFileHistory)

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*

# Integrate JIRA 6.3.9 with FishEye 3.5.3 (this was not tested with other versions)
# Make sure the default [time tracking unit in JIRA is set to 'hours'|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+Time+Tracking]
# Submit time log (e.g., 10m) from a linked Crucible review to the JIRA issue
# Notice that the time submitted, regardless of the unit, will be in hours
In the JIRA issue, it will show the '10m' logged as '1d 2h' (1 day of 8 hours + 2 hours = 10 hours)

Screenshot from Crucible side showing that '10m' have been logged:
!Screen Shot 2014-12-02 at 5.22.54 PM.png!

Screenshot from JIRA side showing that '1d 2h' have been logged:
!Screen Shot 2014-12-02 at 5.23.18 PM.png!

*Workaround:*
Use the default units in JIRA side as minutes and make sure to specify all values that way.

*Note:* 
There's a similar closed bug report (CRUC-6890) but that's supposed to happen only *"when closing review"*.
fields.summary: Time submitted in minutes from Crucible being logged as hours in JIRA issues

Expected behaviour:

fields.summary: Copy/blame buttons in the middle of nowhere

fields.description:
Currently Crucible automatically searches for the relevant file content in the connected repositories after uploading a patch file, making a 'best guess' in its processing. 

As the 'guessing' may be incorrect, it would be great if it were possible to have a default location where to anchor the patch, e.g., the repository trunk.
fields.summary: Default patch anchor location

fields.description:
The Smart Commit command "+review" tells FishEye to create a new review in the project specified with the content of the changeset. The review will be in a draft state unless the project has default reviewers or reviewers are explicitly mentioned. 

It would be useful to be able to start a review that is in Draft state via a Smart Commit at a later date after it has been creating.
fields.summary: Ability to Start a review in Draft state via Smart Commits

fields.description:
Currently the documents in a review are shown under the folders where they are located, but it is not possible to remove an entire folder from a review. It is necessary to remove each file under the folder by clicking in the "x" icon:

!review.png|thumbnail!

The suggestion is to also have an icon to remove the entire folder.
fields.summary: Ability to remove entire folder from review
Irrelevant changes are not hidden in Branch reviews for SVN

fields.description:
Nowadays it is necessary to access each review a user is a participant of in order to sum the time spent on each review. 

It would be great to have a report that would show the total amount of time spent by each user, or by a specific user, over specific time periods.

This query might help:
{code:sql}
SELECT i.cru_proj_key, i.cru_number, u.cru_user_name, SUM(p.cru_time_spent) AS time_spent
FROM cru_review_participant p, cru_user u, cru_review r, cru_revpermaid i 
WHERE p.cru_user = u.cru_user_id
AND p.cru_review_id = r.cru_review_id 
AND i.cru_review_id = r.cru_review_id 
GROUP BY i.cru_proj_key, i.cru_number, u.cru_user_name;
{code}
fields.summary: Report time spent by a user over specific time periods

fields.description:
Crucible does its job at tracking reviews and displaying the diffs but some customers need more. When there has been a large refactoring of code across multiple files, just showing a code diff is not enough to make an informed decision whether the review is complete or not. 
Some customers might need full source navigation provided by tools like cscope (old school C programmers), Eclipse, Source Insight, etc where they can select a variable and it will tell them what it is, who is calling it, etc. 
They might need to search other instances of this code type to see how it was implemented there, etc.

Crucible has a feature called Full Context:
!FullContext.png!

But it can only browse/search a particular file. In some customers' case, separate header files will define the datatype being code inspected in another c/c++ file. 
With code navigation tools, They're able to select a variable in the file they're editing (and hopefully inspecting) and select:
- what type of data it is
- where is this data defined (i.e. header file)
- where is this data used so they can determine other instances where this data is used and whether this particular code under inspection is being used properly.

Crucible is assuming each reviewer knows the layout, architecture, code styles, etc of an entire project. This is impossible and the tool needs this type of functionality for designers to review code in a timely manner.
fields.summary: Full source code navigation in Crucible

fields.description:
When creating a review from the Commit Graph the commit hash is added to the *Objectives* section in the review, but when hovering this hash it says "Changeset not found":
!bug1.png|thumbnail!

When clicking in the hash, the following shows up in the log:
{noformat}
2014-11-17 11:40:52,137 INFO  [qtp675749235-180 ] fisheye ServletUtils-send404 - 404: No such repository: null referer=http://localhost:8060/cru/CR-22
{noformat}
In the browser:
!bug2.png|thumbnail!

h3.Steps to Reproduce
# Navigate into the repository > {{Commit Graph}}.
# Select a commit.
# Click the cog icon > {{Create Review}}.
# Select the project and click in {{Create Review}}.
# Click in {{Done}} to finish the creation.
# Check the commit hash is shown under *Objectives*. Hover it to verify the changeset is not found, then click on it to reproduce the error.

h3.Cause
* As observed in the INFO message in the logs, it is passing the repository value as "null".

h3.Workaround
# In the *Objectives* section, click in *Edit*, then observe the value for *rep* is set to *null*:
!bug3.png|thumbnail!
# Set it to the name of the repository and click to save it:
!bug4.png|thumbnail!
# Hover the hash and observe it is now found:
!bug5.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Creating review from Commit Graph results in Changeset not found

fields.description:

While testing the migration to a new server, I am getting error as "Error synchronising users: Problem communicating with Crowd" and i am unable to login into Crucible with Fisheye Application.

I followed the steps provided in the atlassian site but none worked. Please help me to fix this issue.

Thanks,
Karthikeyan K

fields.summary: Need support to resolve  javax.el.ELException

fields.description:
The "Select project for new review" window that pops up when creating a review from fisheye does not default to the project containing the repository as a default. It seems like the logic should be to check to see if that repo is the default of any project, if there is more than one project then at least start with automatically picking one of them. If your last selected project is one in the list then that should be given priority.

They way the logic works right now when someone works on multiple projects and they do not watch what project is selected here (since sometimes it is right if you want the same project as you were on last), reviews get made in wrong projects.
fields.summary: "Select project for new review" window defaults last selected project.

fields.description: It would be nice if I could setup Crucible to send a weekly report containing the "Review Blockers" report.
fields.summary: Review Blockers Report Automated Email

DeployedThe issue has been deployed into production...

Won't FixThe problem described is an issue which will never be fixed. DuplicateThe problem is a duplicate of an existing issue. IncompleteThe problem is not completely described. fields.description:
Crucible should detect and ignore file changes coming from a trivial merge 

I consider a merge to be trivial when two of the files are binary identical (base==parent1, base==parent2 or parent1==parent2).
The reason is that some merges may include a lot of files that are not modified on one side, we don't necessarily want to review all these files.
Some files may have changes on both branches that to not trigger a conflict, these are the files for which we want to review the merge.

I'll take an example 

-----------------------------------------------
Branch A:
-	File1, files2 and file3 modified
Branch B:
-	File1 modified (assuming non-conflicting change)
-	File2 modified (binary equal to file2 in branch A)

Merge tool is set to kdiff3-noauto (note that behaviour should be the same with other merge tools as they usually dont filter trivial merges in no auto mode).

Merge with option auto-resolve merge = true:
-	all files are merged without popping the merge GUI.

Merge with option auto-resolve merge = false:
-	kdiff3 is started for all files.
-	File1 reports X solved conflicts
-	File2 reports Y solved conflict and "File B and file C are binary equal"
-	File3 reports Z solved conflict and "File A and file C are binary equal"

-----------------------------------------------
Desired behavior (using for example a third option: auto-resolve merge = trivial)
-	kdiff3 is started for file1 only, report X solved conflicts
-	File2 and file3 are merged without starting kdiff3
fields.summary: Crucible should help to distinguish between trivial and non trivial merges

fields.description: Branch review shows commit list which presents commits existing on feature branch and absent on base branch. For Git list is shown almost instantly however for larger non Git repositories it is slow - even several seconds.
fields.summary: Slow commit list for branch reviews

fields.description:
Since version 3.6 Crucible supports Branch reviews, see https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Adding+content+to+the+review#Addingcontenttothereview-Branches
It would be nice to be able to create those reviews automatically, through smart commits, by putting appropriate command into commit log message.
See http://blogs.atlassian.com/2014/10/fisheyecrucible-3-6-branch-reviews-actions-dialog/#comment-193321

fields.description:
When navigating a file using the Page Up and Page Down keys, several lines are skipped. For example, when viewing a file and the last line displayed is 81, after hitting page down, the first line is 87, which skips several lines.

The {{j}}/{{k}} shortcuts are not sufficient as they are used to navigate between elements and if the element is larger than the the window height, then key parts are missed when using page up and down.
fields.summary: Page up and down keys skip several lines in a review

fields.description:
HTR:

# Create a project without a moderator
# Create a review
# Perform the 'action:approveReview' action on the review using either the REST or Java api

Expected:
* Either an error, or (preferably) transitioning the review to the 'Review' state

Actual behavior:
* The review is transition to the 'Awaiting approval' state, which is normally not reachable for projects without moderators
fields.summary: Using the API, you can transition a review to a state that's not normally in the workflow

fields.description:
Hi,

I wanted to extend the plugin myself, but asit turns out, you are not longer open-sourcing the code for it and I was redirected to here to open an issue, so I do :-)

I like the reviewcreator for Crucible, however, in our case we need to skip some branches for automatic review creation, what is currently not possible. For this reason we are currently using customised mullite script but... :-)

Another useful feature would be to make it possible to disable auto-adding the "Created by autoreview plugin" message being added to the reviews.

Hope that makes sense, thanks.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce
1) Go to the source page ( https://fisheye1.atlassian.com/browse/firebird/client-java/src/openoffice/org/firebirdsql/jdbc/oo/OODatabaseMetaData.java?hb=true )
2) scroll down
3) try to select a code
The whole page scrolls to the top.

{color:red}Problem affects safari 7.1, 8 ONLY{color}

* source must be long
* horizontal scroll must be available

It's a bug in Webkit https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=138089
fields.summary: Safari - Selecting a code on source page scroll the whole page
